title: 1. Introduction to Python
summary:
• Python is a high-level, interpreted language known for simplicity.
  • It is used in Web Dev, Data Science, Automation, and AI.
  • Setup requires installing Python and adding it to PATH.
content:
What is Programming?

Programming is the process of giving instructions to a computer to perform specific tasks. It involves writing code in a programming language that the computer can understand and execute.

Why Python?

Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. It is widely used in:

  • Web Development (Django, Flask)
  • Data Science and Machine Learning (Pandas, NumPy, TensorFlow)
  • Automation and Scripting
  • Game Development (Pygame)

Setting Up

To get started, download the latest version from python.org and ensure you check the box to 'Add Python to PATH'.

The 'Hello, World!' Program

Open your IDE (VS Code is recommended) and type the following:

print("Hello, World!")

Output:

Hello, World!

title: 2. Fundamentals & Variables
summary:
• Variables store data and do not need explicit declaration.
  • Common types: int, float, str, bool.
  • Typecasting converts one data type to another.
content:
Variables

Variables are used to store data that can be used and manipulated. A variable is created when you assign a value to it.

name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.6

Data Types

Python supports several built-in data types:

  • Integers (int): Whole numbers (e.g., 10, -5).
  • Floats (float): Decimal numbers (e.g., 3.14).
  • Strings (str): Text data (e.g., "Hello").
  • Booleans (bool): True or False.

Typecasting

Typecasting is the process of converting one data type to another.

num_str = "10"
num_int = int(num_str)
print(num_int) # Output: 10

title: 3. Control Flow
summary:
• Use if, elif, else for decision making.
  • Use for loops for sequences and while loops for conditions.
  • Control loops with break, continue, and pass.
content:
If-Else Statements

Conditional statements allow you to execute code based on certain conditions.

age = 18
if age < 18:
    print("Minor")
elif age == 18:
    print("Just became an adult")
else:
    print("Adult")

Loops

For Loops

Used to iterate over a sequence like a list or range.

for i in range(5):
    print(i) # Prints 0 to 4

While Loops

Executes as long as a condition is True.

count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

title: 4. Strings
summary:
• Strings are immutable sequences of characters.
  • Slicing [start:stop:step] allows you to extract substrings.
  • f-strings are the modern way to format text.
content:
Creating Strings

Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes. Triple quotes are used for multi-line strings.

Slicing

You can extract parts of a string using slicing syntax text[start:stop:step].

text = "Python"
print(text[0:2]) # Py
print(text[::-1]) # nohtyP (Reverse)

String Methods

Python provides built-in methods for manipulation:

  • .upper(): Converts to uppercase.
  • .strip(): Removes whitespace.
  • .replace(old, new): Replaces substrings.

f-Strings

Introduced in Python 3.6, f-strings are the most concise way to format strings.

name = "Alice"
print(f"Hello, {name}!")

title: 5. Functions & Modules
summary:
• Functions promote reusability.
  • Lambda functions are anonymous one-liners.
  • Modules organize code; pip installs external libraries.
content:
Defining Functions

Functions are defined using the def keyword.

def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))

Lambda Functions

Small, anonymous functions defined with the lambda keyword.

square = lambda x: x**2
print(square(4)) # 16

Scope

Variables inside functions are local. Variables outside are global. Use the global keyword to modify global variables inside a function.

title: 6. Data Structures
summary:
• List: Ordered, Mutable [ ].
  • Tuple: Ordered, Immutable ( ).
  • Set: Unordered, Unique { }.
  • Dictionary: Key-Value Pairs { : }.
content:
Lists

Ordered and mutable collections.

nums = [1, 2, 3]
nums.append(4) # [1, 2, 3, 4]

Tuples

Immutable collections. Faster than lists and used as dictionary keys.

coords = (10, 20)

Dictionaries

Store data in key-value pairs for fast lookups.

student = {"name": "Alice", "age": 25}
print(student["name"])

title: 7. Object-Oriented Programming
summary:
• Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods.
  • Inheritance: Deriving new classes from existing ones.
  • Polymorphism: Same interface, different implementation.
content:
Classes and Objects

A class is a blueprint; an object is an instance of that blueprint.

class Dog:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

    def bark(self):
        print(f"{self.name} says Woof!")

Inheritance

Allows a child class to reuse logic from a parent class.

class Animal:
    def speak(self):
        pass

class Cat(Animal):
    def speak(self):
        print("Meow")

title: 8. Advanced Concepts
summary:
• Decorators modify function behavior.
  • @property allows getter/setter logic with attribute syntax.
  • Static methods don't require class or instance access.
content:
Decorators

Wrappers that modify the behavior of functions.

def my_decorator(func):
    def wrapper():
        print("Before")
        func()
        print("After")
    return wrapper

Getters & Setters

Use the @property decorator to control attribute access pythonically.

class Person:
    @property
    def name(self):
        return self._name

title: 9. Magic Methods
summary:
• Dunder methods start/end with double underscores.
  • __init__ initializes objects.
  • __str__ defines string representation.
content:
Introduction

Magic methods allow you to define how objects behave with operators like +, -, ==.

Common Methods

  • __init__: Constructor.
  • __str__: Human-readable string representation.
  • __add__: Defines behavior for the + operator.
def __str__(self):
    return f"Person({self.name})"

title: 10. Error Handling
summary:
• Try/Except blocks prevent crashes.
  • Finally runs cleanup code regardless of errors.
  • Raise allows triggering custom exceptions.
content:
Try-Except

Handle errors gracefully instead of crashing.

try:
    x = 10 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Cannot divide by zero!")
finally:
    print("Execution complete.")

Custom Exceptions

You can define your own error types by inheriting from Exception.

title: 11. File I/O & OS
summary:
• 'r' for read, 'w' for write, 'a' for append.
  • Use 'with' statements to automatically close files.
  • The os module handles directory operations.
content:
Reading and Writing

The with statement is recommended as it handles closing files automatically.

with open("data.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello World")

with open("data.txt", "r") as f:
    print(f.read())

OS Module

Use os to interact with the operating system.

import os
print(os.getcwd()) # Get current directory

title: 12. External Libraries
summary:
• Virtual Environments isolate dependencies.
  • pip is the package installer.
  • Requests handles API calls; Regex handles pattern matching.
content:
Virtual Environments

Isolate project dependencies using venv.

python -m venv my_env

Requests Module

Simplifies HTTP requests to APIs.

import requests
response = requests.get("https://api.github.com")

Regex

Pattern matching using the re module.

import re
match = re.search("pattern", text)
